Award.AwardTitle: Final stages of breakup and early spreading history of the Eastern North America passive margin from multichannel seismic data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rifted passive margins record the full geologic history of rifting, from rift onset to continental breakup to the initiation of seafloor spreading and post-rift evolution of the margin. This project focuses on the Eastern North America continental margin offshore Cape Hatteras that was formed after the breakup of supercontinent Pangaea. A large suite of data has been collected across the transition from continental crust to oceanic crust in this region. These data will be analyzed and interpreted to obtain an improved understanding of events surrounding the final stage of continental breakup including the relationship between the timing of rifting and the occurrence of offshore magmatism and early opening of the Central Atlantic Ocean. The project will also provide new information on landslides that have occurred along the margin of the U.S. and an estimate of the number of landslides that might have produced tsunamis. A postdoctoral researcher will be trained in geophysical data analysis and interpretation, and the results of the proposed work will be incorporated into outreach programs for high school and middle school students.

This project consists of the processing and interpretation of offshore, long-offset multichannel seismic (MCS) data from the Eastern North American Margin. The long-offset MCS data analysis will provide critical new information about the along-strike variations of the complex transitional crust between unambiguous continental and oceanic crust at a smaller-scale than previous studies. The crustal-scale closely-spaced MCS profiles will be essential to image the small-scale heterogeneities of the volcanic products along the margin, spatial patterns in basement topography, thickness of sediment and rift unconformities within the sediments and features within the crust and lithosphere (e.g., faults and crustal thickness variations). MCS imaging of those features are needed to assess the late-stage rifting processes and variations in time and space of these processes. Different kinematic plate models for the earliest stage of evolution of the Central Atlantic Ocean make very different predictions for the half spreading rate. In addition, large-scale segmentation at the modern Mid-Atlantic ridge has also been proposed to be inherited from the geometry of the adjacent continental margin. MCS data from this project will constrain variations in basement roughness, crustal thickness and crustal structure and reflectivity along and across new oceanic crust that will provide important constraints on the early seafloor spreading history and will help to distinguish between competing models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Passive margins form where continental rifts result in the successful separation of continents and the formation of new oceans. Although rifting is one of the fundamental processes of plate tectonics, at many passive margins worldwide, questions remains about the factors and underlying processes that are most important in influencing their development. This project focuses on the continental margin off the coast of the eastern U.S. that formed with the Mesozoic breakup of supercontinent Pangea. This rifting event is known to have been accompanied by extensive magmatism. Key information that are critically missing to fully understand its formation includes the relationship between short-lived flood basalt episode onshore and breakup magmatism offshore and the timing and duration of the transition from continental breakup to seafloor spreading. This project involved the analysis of existing marine seismic data collected across the margin offshore North Carolina in 2014 as part of a community seismic experiment. The processing and interpretation of the new seismic data provided new information about deep crustal structure of this margin and shed new light on the events surroundings final stages of breakup and early spreading history of the Central Atlantic. This project supported a postdoctoral research scientist.

Our study has revealed and characterized several previously unknown features and factors that contributed to the formation of the eastern north American margin offshore North Carolina. First, the results from 2D forward magnetic modeling of the wide, positive, high amplitude east coast magnetic anomaly placed new constraints on the extension rates during breakup at this margin and provided a rough estimate of the breakup duration. Secondly, the long-offset multichannel seismic data provide evidence of very limited magmatism during the early spreading history with thin new igneous crust and with basement roughness values typical of very-slow and slow spreading oceanic crusts. These results combined with results from coincident refraction data modeling and petrologic models from collaborators suggest that the earliest igneous crust is best explained by the continued presence of continental mantle lithosphere that prevents shallow melting. Given the new extension rates derived from the forward magnetic modeling and very-slow spreading rates derived from the basement roughness of earliest fully igneous crust, we attribute the persistence of mantle continental lithosphere to conductive cooling at slow extension rates. Lastly, we image a step-up in the basement at the Blake Spur magnetic anomaly. The modeling of the magnetic data suggests that the step-up in the basement can explain the shape and amplitude of this anomaly that had remained enigmatic. This would indicate that this magnetic is not a common seafloor anomaly as previously proposed. We interpret the step up in the basement as well as thickening of the crust at the Blake Spur magnetic anomaly time as the onset of normal seafloor spreading.
